history.content:
126 needs multiple integrals and coordinate changes. (All probability courses that invoke joint densities are going to have to deal with this.) This is a topic covered in 53. However, it is not impossible to learn if you are dedicated and have friends who can teach you.

127 definitely needs gradients and Lagrange multipliers for example. (All optimization courses beyond linear programming are going to deal with this, and frankly, they are basically hanging out beneath the surface even in discussions of LPs.) These are topics covered in 53. However, it is not impossible to learn if you are dedicated and have friends who can teach you.

127 tends to review much of the linear algebra that it uses. It would of course be beneficial to have 16B under your belt, but again, it is possible to catch up if you walk in with both eyes open and a willingness to work hard.

Dedicated here means willing to do substantial work beyond the assigned homeworks. Neither 126 nor 127 will probably give you the quantity of HW you will need to make this stuff solid. You will have to exercise beyond that point to make sure you get it.

Really, students in the department should consider Math 53 to be a de-facto requirement *unless* you are following a particularly narrow very traditional software-engineering path in which these ideas aren't a critical part of the background. But as optimization and inference ideas continue to become more and more mainstream in the conceptual toolkit for software engineering, this particular path is growing more and more narrow.

126 sometimes needs multiple integrals and coordinate changes. (All probability courses that invoke joint densities are going to have to deal with this.) This is a topic covered in 53. However, it is not impossible to learn if you are dedicated and have friends who can teach you.

127 definitely needs gradients and Lagrange multipliers for example. (All optimization courses beyond linear programming are going to deal with this, and frankly, they are basically hanging out beneath the surface even in discussions of LPs.) These are topics covered in 53. However, it is not impossible to learn if you are dedicated and have friends who can teach you.

127 tends to review much of the linear algebra that it uses. It would of course be beneficial to have 16B under your belt, but again, it is possible to catch up if you walk in with both eyes open and a willingness to work hard.

Dedicated here means willing to do substantial work beyond the assigned homeworks. Neither 126 nor 127 will probably give you the quantity of HW you will need to make this stuff solid. You will have to exercise beyond that point to make sure you get it.

Really, students in the department should consider Math 53 to be a de-facto requirement *unless* you are following a particularly narrow very traditional software-engineering path in which these ideas aren't a critical part of the background. But as optimization and inference ideas continue to become more and more mainstream in the conceptual toolkit for software engineering, this particular path is growing more and more narrow.

children.subject: Thank you so much professor! I was originally planning to take 53 online over the summer but I need to ask myself if I can do an engineering internship simultaneously. I will try my best to get 53 in before I take 126/127.

history.content:
I'm a CS major and I intend to take EE126 and EE127 (but not 189) before I graduate, and I have 3 semesters left. I'm planning to enroll in EE126 next fall and take EE127 next spring. By the time I take EE126, I will have taken 16A, 70,170,188, and Math 54 (note the exclusion of Math 53 and 16B). Would I be fairly equipped to take these classes?

Thanks!
history.subject: Pre-requisites for EE126/EE127?
